node.title: heat conduction betwwen blocks
node.bodyText:
Hi, I am trying to simulate a heat conduction bettwen two blocks.
I found the example file at /moose/modules/heat_conduction/test/tests/sideset_heat_transfer/cfem_gap.i and referred the InterfaceKernel/gap_01 in my file. When I  run it, I got the error: Variable and neighbor variable are the same, but they are not elemental variables.
I don't kown why, beacause the variables in example file are also nodal variables.
Here is my file:
[Mesh]
  file = inputmesh1.e
[]

[Variables]
  [./temp]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
    initial_condition = 0
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]

  [hc]
    type = HeatConduction
    variable = temp
  []
  [time_derivative]
    type = HeatConductionTimeDerivative
    variable = temp
  []

  [./diff]
    type = Diffusion
    variable = temp
  [../]

[]

[InterfaceKernels]
  # Side set kernel to represent heat transfer across blocks
  # Automatically uses the materials defined in SideSetHeatTransferMaterial
  [gap_01]
    type = SideSetHeatTransferKernel
    # This variable defined on a given block must match the primary_block given when the side set was generated
    variable = temp
    # This variable defined on a given block must match the paired_block given when the side set was generated
    neighbor_var = temp
    boundary = interface
  []
[]
[BCs]
  [./right]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = temp
    boundary = right
    value = 40
  [../]
  [hbc]
    type = HeatConductionBC
    boundary = right
    variable = temp
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [hcm]
    type = HeatConductionMaterial
    specific_heat = 1
    thermal_conductivity = 1
  []

  [density]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = '680'
  []
  [gap_mat]
    type = SideSetHeatTransferMaterial
    boundary = interface
    conductivity = 1
    gap_length = 0.002
    Tbulk = 750
    h_primary = 3000
    h_neighbor = 3000
    emissivity_primary = 0.85
    emissivity_neighbor = 0.85
  []

[]


[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  start_time = 0
  dt = 1
  num_steps = 10
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

Hello
First, are you trying to model heat transfer across a gap? If there is no gap you dont need this interface kernel.
If you are, then use MONOMIAL instead of LAGRANGE, as in the example.
A nodal variable cannot be discontinuous between two elements, since it can only have a single value on each node shared by the two elements.
Guillaume
In fact, there is no gap. Do you mean remove the interfacekernel? I did it, but the result looks not normal.

I found the reason. All boundaries are need to be set HeatConductionBC.
Thank you

node.title: about heat conduction transfer boundary
node.bodyText: Hi, I made a heat transfer model. The result is shown in the figure. I used the boundary condition of heatcondutionBC between the two layers of materials. I wonder if it is reasonable. Since my heat transfer result is not ideal, I wonder if I need to add other conditions? For example, there seems to be no heat transfer in the internal pellets. Also, what is the difference between ADHeat Conduction and HeatConduction？

Hello
It looks weird? The temperature seems to be oscillating.
Do you need a BC in between the two layers? If you wanted to model a special interface / a thin heat resistance from the contact between the two layers, I would use an interface kernel.
If you just want to model regular thermal conduction, then there is a no need for a boundary condition, the kernels already apply the right equation at the boundary between the two materials.
The difference between ADHeatConduction and HeatConduction is automatic differentiation (AD) in the first one. AD is used to compute numerically perfect derivatives for the Jacobian, especially with complex material properties (heat conductivity here).
See more information here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/modules/phase_field/FunctionMaterials/AutomaticDifferentiation.html
Guillaume

Thank you. I have another question. Why is there a negative value in heat transfer? That doesn't seem to fit the laws of physics.






发自我的iPhone
…
------------------ Original ------------------
From: Guillaume Giudicelli ***@***.***>
Date: Fri,Jan 28,2022 11:41 PM
To: idaholab/moose ***@***.***>
Cc: amosaha ***@***.***>, Author ***@***.***>
Subject: Re: [idaholab/moose] about heat conduction transfer boundary(Discussion #20162)






Hello

It looks weird? The temperature seems to be oscillating.
 Do you need a BC in between the two layers? If you wanted to model a special interface / a thin heat resistance from the contact between the two layers, I would use an interface kernel.
 If you just want to model regular thermal conduction, then there is a no need for a boundary condition, the kernels already apply the right equation.

The difference between ADHeatConduction and HeatConduction is automatic differentiation (AD) in the first one. AD is used to compute numerically perfect derivatives for the Jacobian, especially with complex material properties (heat conductivity here).
 See more information here:
 https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/modules/phase_field/FunctionMaterials/AutomaticDifferentiation.html

Guillaume

—
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.
Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS or Android.
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID: ***@***.***>
The problem is probably not correctly defined. The solution solves the equations that it is being fed, if there's issues with them the solution can be unphysical.

node.title: Use previous simulation result for next time step
node.bodyText:
Hello, I would like to know a way to use previous simulation result for the next time step.
Here is the situation that I have
Transient: 0 -> 0.1 -> 0.2 -> 0.4, can be done in just one simulation
Steady: 0 -> 0.1 /  0.1 -> 0.2 / 0.2 -> 0.4, can bedone in "Three" simulations
I want to know how to inherit previous simulation status for the new(next) simulation.
In other words, how to initialize variables and conditions by using previous simulation result?
Have a look at SolutionUserObject. Also, see Restarting and recovering from previous simulations page.  There will be some posts on this topic.

node.title: Postprocessor for Local Values
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone!
Is there a way to record and display the value of a variable or material property at a certain location on the domain? It seems that I can record the mean value across the domain through the ElementAverageValue and ElementAverageMaterial Property postprocessors, or I can record the sum through the ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor and ElementIntegralMaterialProperty postprocessors, but I'm trying to track precise values at specific points. Thank you for all that you do!

You can check VectorPostprocessors System.
  PointValueSampler may be useful
This is exactly what I need, thank you!

node.title: runing tests failed
node.bodyText:
Dear all.
I just started learning moose. When I installed moose to the step "./run_tests -j4 "according to tutorial, it showed that some tests about "fvkernels" failed. I would like to know how to solve this situation.
Thanks

Hello
Do these tests pass when ran individually? (go in test/tests/fvkernels/mms and run the test there, or in test/tests/fvkernels/one-var-diffusion actually, that's a simpler test)
And you should have more information higher in the run_tests log, could you please paste it for some of the tests here?
Guillaume

node.title: Phase field model for two phase system
node.bodyText:
Hi
I want to model two phases eta1 and eta2  (eta1+eta2=1). I am using SwitchingFunctionConstraintEta for sum of order parameter at a point to be 1. My eta1 kernels are AllenCahn and ACInterface and SwitchingFunctionConstraintEta and TimeDerivative.(Total 4)
Ques.1 Do I have to put these kernels again for eta2 or just SwitchingConstraintEta is enough ?
Ques.2 When I model using eta only and other phase as (1-eta) I get convergence using DerivativeTwoPhaseMaterial but when I am trying same problem using eta1 and eta2 separately with DerivativeMultiPhaseMaterial and MultiBarrierFunctionMaterial properties there is a convergence issue. Can we solve the same problem like the later approach?
RESOLVED

node.title: Is the order of stress and strain components correct in AbaqusUMATStress?
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Team,
In AbaqusUMATStress.C the ordering of the stress and strain seems to be different from the Abaqus convention:
https://abaqus-docs.mit.edu/2017/English/SIMACAEMODRefMap/simamod-c-conventions.htm
In Abaqus the ordering of the stress vector is:
sigma_{xx}, sigma_{yy}, sigma_{zz}, sigma_{xy}, sigma_{xz}, sigma_{yz}
however, the way stress[qp] is assigned at line 283 of AbaqusUMATStress is different
because the RankTwoTensor constructor follow another convention where sigma{yz} and  sigma{xy}
are inverted.
I was investigating this problem because of convergence issues I was facing when using the UMAT plugin.
Basically the model converged well with one element but gave wrong results as soon as more elements were used.
This problem was reported by @edwardXZ06 some time ago:
#19574
but I jumped too quickly to the conclusion that the timestepper was the problem.
Now I tried changing line 174 with the strain components order:
{{0, 0}, {1, 1}, {2, 2}, {0, 1}, {0, 2},{1, 2} }};
and the stress at line 284 to:
_aqSTRESS[0], _aqSTRESS[1], _aqSTRESS[2], _aqSTRESS[5], _aqSTRESS[4], _aqSTRESS[3]);
and all the convergence problems disappeared and I can get the same results as in Abaqus.
Of course, if my UMAT is adapted one can use the current AbaqusUMATStress,
however, I think the idea here is to provide compatibility between Abaqus UMAT and MOOSE,
therefore it would be better to follow Abaqus convention here.
Should AbaqusUMATStress be changed? Can you please check?
Thank you
Best Regards,
Nicolò

Thanks for bringing this up. Opened an issue: #20111.
Definitely, our intention is to provide compatibility and not add additional steps on the user side.

Dear @recuero
Also, the order of the components of _aqDDSDDE
that are provided to fillSymmetric21FromInputVector
to give the _jacobian_mult
may be wrong for the same reason.
I will analyse this and let you know.
The reason why this bug cannot be noticed in the tests
is because on one element with pure tension BC there is no shear strain or stress
so you will not notice the difference.
Best Regards,
Nicolò
Thank you for opening the issue

You are right. The order of Jacobian entries coming from UMAT does not match MOOSE's convention for the same reasons. The changes in #20112 improve the Jacobian coming from UMAT for a problem where shear stiffness depends on the direction. I tested that on a one-element problem, but should work also for other problems (not sure what constitutive equations you are using).

@recuero  Thank you very much for this, at a first glance it looks correct.
I am using an anisotropic elasto-plastic model, therefore I will check with the new jacobian and I should be able to see some changes in the convergence rate.
I will let you know if there are further problems.
Best Regards,
Nicolò

node.title: Missing library libtimpi_opt.so.6 after update
node.bodyText:
I updated moose yesterday and ran into following issue when I tried running my project:
./intro-opt: error while loading shared libraries: libtimpi_opt.so.6: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
Running ldd myproject-opt gives the result libtimpi_opt.so.6 => not found
Please help me fix this. Thanks!

Hello
Did you update both MOOSE and libmesh? Like you followed the instructions here?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/index.html#update
Guillaume
Ah, just forgot make clobberall. Thank you.

node.title: elem_side_builder.h missing in moose-libmesh
node.bodyText:
I updated my moose environment today and the previously working project failed building with:
moose_projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/Assembly.h:24:10: fatal error: libmesh/elem_side_builder.h: No such file or directory
   24 | #include "libmesh/elem_side_builder.h"
      |          ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
compilation terminated.

The versions installed in the moose environment are reported as up-to-date as well:
$ conda list
# packages in environment at /home/hans/miniconda3/envs/moose:
#
# Name                    Version                   Build  Channel
moose-libmesh             2021.10.27              build_0    idaholab
moose-libmesh-vtk         6.3.0                   build_7    idaholab

I inspected the header in the environment and indeed, this header file is missing, whereas all the other elem* header are present:
~/miniconda3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/libmesh$ ls elem*.h
elem_assembly.h  elem_cutter.h  elem.h  elem_hash.h  elem_internal.h  elem_quality.h  elem_range.h

According to the docs, for instance
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/libmesh/files.html
it should be there. I also tried reupdating everything, reinstalling libmesh, nothing helped.
Please help me to fix this. Thanks in advance!

Hello
2021.10.27 is too old, the conda update failed.
The easiest thing to do is to wipe out the environment and re-run the conda commands to re-create it
guillaume

Well it does not say so:
conda update --all
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done
Solving environment: done

# All requested packages already installed.

But it might be not completely correct here...

Yeah the dependency resolution does not allow a newer update at this point
It thinks it’s up to date
this is why you ll have to wipe it

I just saw @GiudGiud post. But I am going to continue posting mine...
You are also using our older idaholab channel. The new channel is:
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
Be sure to remove the old one:
conda config --remove channels idaholab
This older channel will someday be removed.
Also, you may wish to upgrade to mamba. It is a much quicker Conda package installer.
Also.... the inability to upgrade is probably due to the fact a python version in moose-tools is preventing it. You should probably wipe the entire 'moose' environment, and reinstall, for the least amount of headaches.
Wiping the whole environment and upgrading to mamba solved it. Thanks for the fast and efficient help!
FYI - not sure who added it, but adding [Solved] to the title prefix isn't necessary. Marking as "answered" is sufficient!

node.title: Peacock segmentation fault on Mac Monterey
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am having problem when trying to run peacock on my Mac Monterey:
( ~ % mamba activate moose
~ % cd ~/projects/moose
moose % peacock
No executable found for method type(s): opt, dbg, oprof, devel
zsh: segmentation fault  peacock )
rocess:               python3.7 [46382]
Path:                  /Users/USER/*/python
Identifier:            python3.7
Version:               ???
Code Type:             X86-64 (Translated)
Parent Process:        zsh [45795]
Responsible:           Terminal [45793]
User ID:               501
Date/Time:             2022-01-24 19:04:20.6359 +0800
OS Version:            macOS 12.0.1 (21A559)
Report Version:        12
Anonymous UUID:        9E42E1B1-160E-DCEC-5CB4-4D30DB93E2F3
Sleep/Wake UUID:       B72ACBDD-7B44-42E5-8462-ADC38D2438DD
Time Awake Since Boot: 11000 seconds
Time Since Wake:       5309 seconds
System Integrity Protection: enabled
Crashed Thread:        0  Dispatch queue: com.apple.main-thread
Exception Type:        EXC_BAD_ACCESS (SIGSEGV)
Exception Codes:       KERN_INVALID_ADDRESS at 0x0000000000000131
Exception Codes:       0x0000000000000001, 0x0000000000000131
Exception Note:        EXC_CORPSE_NOTIFY
Termination Reason:    Namespace SIGNAL, Code 11 Segmentation fault: 11
Terminating Process:   exc handler [46382]
Is there any solution to this issue? Thanks in advance!

The error is indicating you must first build a binary for which Peacock can interface with. For MOOSE, this usually means either building the test suite, or modules:
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make
# or
cd ~/projects/moose/modules
make
Once either (or both) of those locations are built, you can then invoke peacock while somewhere within that path:
cd ~/projects/moose/test/tests/kernels/simple_diffusion
peacock -i simple_diffusion.i
#       ^instructing peacock to run the simple_diffusion.i input file in this directory
peacock is designed to search for a binary in this current directory. If not found, it goes 'up' one directory and searches there. It does this until it can't go up any more directories.
